Bryan Ansong
        
              
          Journey to Assessments.lol Launch - Dev Log #1

How I came up with the idea for Assessments.lol

During my internship at Meta this past summer (Meta U program), I went from zero to full stack development in a few weeks, learning a ton about building software. As you start to learn about new tools and technologies, you start seeing opportunities everywhere.

One day, I was on Levels.fyi checking what my salary at Meta could look like if I was full-time😂, and then the idea struck me: What if there was a similar platform for looking up online assessment scores?

The idea kept resurfacing in my mind, especially when I saw members of the ColorStack community frequently asking questions like "is 470 a good CodeSignal score?" It became clear there was a gap to fill. There was a need for a solution – a platform where candidates could benchmark their technical assessment scores.

To validate this idea, I created a waitlist to gauge interest in such a platform. The response was amazing!

In under 48 hours, over 140 people signed up! 🤯

This confirmed that I wasn’t alone and that candidates need a reliable way to benchmark their OA scores. When there's a need, there's an opportunity – and I'm excited to be the one building the solution!

Takeaway: The more tools/tech you learn, the more ideas you get!

-----------------------------------

For those new to my Dev Logs, assessments.lol is a platform for sharing anonymous, crowdsourced data about technical assessments at top companies. I’m sharing my thoughts and progress publicly to keep me accountable and this is one of the Dev Logs of the journey. I’m learning a lot along the way so if you have any valuable input please share them in the comments!

Join the waitlist here: https://lnkd.in/emxD58bM

Stay tuned for the next dev log! 🌟

#BuildInPublic #devlog

Puja Chaudhury
        
              
          If you're into ML or physics, you might have heard about Physics-Informed Neural Networks, or PINNs. 

These networks have been making waves in the scientific community lately, especially when it comes to solving Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) that pop up in fields like fluid dynamics and structural engineering.

So let's talk about it, today.

Usually, engineers and scientists use methods like Finite Element Modeling (FEM) to solve these equations. FEM works, but it can be slow and might not play nice with data from sensors and other sources. That's where PINNs come in. They take a fresh approach by baking the physics right into the neural network's training process. This not only makes things faster but can also give more accurate results.

To get a feel for how PINNs work, let's think about modeling how temperature changes along a rod using the heat equation, a classic PDE. With PINNs, we build a neural network that spits out the temperature at any point on the rod, at any time.

To train this network, we use a loss function that focuses on the residual of the heat equation at different spots in the domain, which we call colocation points. By placing these points strategically, we make sure the network learns the right temperature distribution based on the physics of heat transfer. The heat equation,

∂u/∂t = α ∂²u/∂x²,

where u is temperature, t is time, x is position along the rod, and α is thermal diffusivity, is the foundation for the training process.

By making the network's predictions match the known behavior from the heat equation at the colocation points, the neural network learns to stick to the physical laws that govern heat distribution. This lets the PINN predict temperature even where we don't have direct measurements, which is a powerful tool for tackling complex physics problems using machine learning.

I actually tried this myself recently by using PINNs to solve the heat equation for a rod. I used a library called JAX (which I am still learning), which is great for automatic differentiation. It was a cool experience that showed me how PINNs could be used in real-world situations. :)

Check out my code: https://lnkd.in/ehfFypQK
Check out the paper: https://lnkd.in/ebgb2TgP
Definitely Checkout Professor Brunton's playlist on this, he's the OG 🙌 : https://lnkd.in/ecUnwKsS

          The Babel Effect: Multilingual Performance Discrepancies in LLMs

Excited to share my research, "The Babel Effect," which explores performance gaps in Large Language Models (LLMs) between high-resource languages like English and low-resource ones like Nepali.

The paper dives into tokenization challenges, data scarcity, and training inefficiencies. We propose solutions like data augmentation and improved tokenization to address these issues.

Aqib Syed
        
              
          I'm excited to share the first version of my EE 263 Course Notes. I’ve been working on these notes over the past few months, starting back when I TA'd EE 263 - Linear Dynamical Systems this past Summer. The course is offered by the Electrical Engineering Department at Stanford. It’s also cross-listed with the Institute for Computational and Mathematical Engineering (ICME).
The course is mainly intended for first-year Ph.D. students in engineering fields (like Electrical Engineering, Aero/Astro, etc.), and it’s a recommended prerequisite for the Convex Optimization course, EE 364a. Having taken EE 263 before EE 364a, I can say firsthand how crucial it is in helping you understand the material for the latter course.
EE 263 focuses on applied linear algebra and dynamical systems, covering core concepts like range, null space, matrix exponentials, as well as very relevant applications, like least-squares estimates.
While assisting in teaching the course, I often heard from students that the lecture slides alone weren’t always enough for them to fully grasp the material.
To help with this, I started writing more detailed notes that expand on the course content. These notes are helpful as a companion to the lectures but aren't completely self-contained—especially in the sections on linear dynamical systems. I plan to continue adding more content and examples over the coming months.
One part of these notes I’m particularly proud of is the plots and visualizations/figures I made to explain key concepts, which were created using some convex combination of LaTeX, Julia and Python.
Here is the link to the notes:
https://lnkd.in/ggBNKQ8E

Pratham Soneja
        
              
          Day 5 of learning in public 🚀 

Traditional fine-tuning methods for large language models often face challenges like high computational requirements, catastrophic forgetting, and single-task specialization. Enter LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation), a game-changing technique that addresses these limitations, enabling efficient and practical fine-tuning of large language models.

LoRA introduces a novel approach to fine-tuning by adding a small number of task-specific weights to the pre-trained model instead of updating all the weights. Here's how it works:

1. Low-Rank Matrices: For each layer in the pre-trained model, LoRA introduces a pair of low-rank matrices: one for the weights and one for the biases.

2. Adaptation: During fine-tuning, LoRA updates these low-rank matrices instead of modifying the pre-trained weights directly.

3. Composition: At inference time, the low-rank matrices are composed with the pre-trained weights to produce the final, adapted weights for the fine-tuned model.

The low-rank nature of these matrices is the key to LoRA's efficiency, dramatically reducing the memory and computational requirements for fine-tuning. This makes it possible to adapt large language models even on consumer-grade hardware like CPUs or edge devices.

But LoRA's advantages don't stop there. It can match or even outperform the performance of full fine-tuning while using far fewer updatable parameters. Additionally, the LoRA updates are reversible, allowing the model to revert to its original state, and composable, enabling a single pre-trained model to be fine-tuned for multiple tasks simultaneously.

To illustrate the power of LoRA, let's dive into a practical example. Here, I'll demonstrate how to implement LoRA from scratch and fine-tune the DistilBERT model using LoRA on the IMDB dataset for sentiment analysis.

https://lnkd.in/g-Tz2NU7

As you can see, LoRA is a remarkable technique that addresses the limitations of traditional fine-tuning methods, making it more efficient, practical, and versatile. By introducing low-rank, task-specific updates, LoRA enables efficient adaptation while preserving the model's original knowledge and allowing for multi-task specialization.

As the demand for deploying large language models on resource-constrained devices continues to grow, techniques like LoRA will make these powerful models more accessible and practical.

Josh Chang
        
              
          🌉 Dead Week at UC Berkeley 🌉
May has swept through Berkeley, bringing with it the annual tradition known as Dead Week. As the buzz of Telegraph Avenue dims slightly, we undergrads know it’s our cue to hunker down and hit the books one last time before finals. Here are some key points I've been focusing on as we wrap up this dead week!

Lesson 1: Structure in Chaos
Berkeley’s Dead Week is ironically alive with a flurry of review sessions and last-minute project deadlines. I've found that a structured approach—breaking down study sessions into focused blocks—helps me navigate this intense week. The serene backdrop of the Bay Area, from the calming waters by the marina to the redwoods around campus, provides the perfect study break scenery to clear my mind and reset.

Lesson 2: The Strength of Shared Struggles
There's something about the communal silence of Mainstacks Library during Dead Week that reminds you you're not alone. Joining forces with other students, we grind out practice exams and Pomodoro sessions until 2 am. It's these moments of collaboration that transform challenging content into shared victories.

Lesson 3: Well-being as a Priority
Dead Week at Berkeley is not just about academic survival but also about maintaining well-being amidst the madness. I make it a point to keep up with my runs through the Fire Trails, ensuring that my mental and physical health aren’t sidelined during these critical times.

Lesson 4: Reflection and Readiness
As I review notes and practice problems, I’m also reflecting on how each semester builds more than just technical skills. It hones resilience, deepens patience, and expands my understanding of what I can achieve under pressure.

With finals on the horizon, I feel prepared and eager to tackle the challenges ahead. To my peers also in the midst of Dead Week, let’s push through to the finish line with determination and spirit! 💪

What are your Dead Week strategies? Let’s share some wisdom and encouragement as we gear up for finals! 🚀 #UCBerkeley #ComputerScience #DeadWeek #FinalsPreparation #GoBears

Oleg Kaganovich
        
              
          2024 was a year of learning. I learned:

• How to slap the bass (yep!)
• Linear Algebra
• Integral Calculus
• Data Science-Driven Statistics 

I also learned that many community college systems still operate on archaic platforms and outdated processes. 

• I had to enroll in 11 (yes, eleven) colleges in order to successfully navigate and register for the 6 classes I targeted.

• Some colleges declined to permit my enrollment in higher math courses because I had completed the prerequisite math class more than two decades ago 🤦🏻‍♂️

And through this process, I’ve learned that online programs like Khan Academy do excellent work supporting students at any level to succeed. I spent 45 days refreshing my understanding of calculus, to then succeed with Calc 2.

Many of today’s colleges seem to be out of step with today’s educational needs. And if they don’t figure out how to ride the tsunami of online learning (and yes, AI), they risk being consumed by this same wave, in the depths of irrelevance.

So on to 2025! I plan to learn multivariable calculus, Python, and then on to robotics and machine learning.

And yes, I’m already learning how to walk the bass! 🎸

#lifelonglearning #ai #startupadvisor

          🚀 Update on our FYP: Early Retirement: A Game with Live NPC Interaction Using LLMs 🎮

The day started pretty bad as I was training my model on COLAB, which was giving great results—up to 87% training accuracy and almost the same with validation accuracy. I left it and went to sleep as it took more than 2 hours to complete 50% of the training. I was expecting the same progress, so I went to sleep, keeping the system on. To my unfortunate luck, when I woke up, the GPU time had run out, dragging the whole progress back to 0. 😓

So, it was basically a task assigned to me, and now it has been changed to check different models' working accuracy on this dataset, like LSTM, GRU, and CONV1D, among others. Can't say much about whether I will continue completing this or not due to time limitations and all, but we'll see that later. 🤔

Until then, keep supporting and connecting to ride along on this FYP journey! 🙌

Ajay Mallya
        
              
          I'm grateful to have had the opportunity to travel back to dear NYC for a couple of days and present about some fundamental theoretical components of the Aerospike vector database. Thank you Microsoft and PyData NYC for hosting and putting on this event, and thank you Arthur Anderson for your wonderful portion of the presentation! (Side remark: after the presentation, I was absolutely stoked when someone told me that I should be a professor after college 😄)

I'm taking advantage of this post to provide a few small updates: Going forward, I'll be working on more software engineering tasks with the Aerospike Graph team, and I'll simultaneously learn more about distributed systems, get deeper into algorithmic design & analysis, and spend more time with C++. I plan to post something more reflective about my gap semester experience and what I have learned , but here is a list of some other things that I have enjoyed recently outside of my internship:

- 📓 Reengaging with my Applied Mathematics courses in nontraditional ways. Without exams to study for, I've taken full advantage of this time to relearn a slew of topics from original principles, and this has been a tremendously fruitful and satisfying process. Additionally, considering the context in which mathematical concepts were discovered has boosted my appreciation for my interests. I highly recommend "The History of Mathematical Proof in Ancient Traditions" by Karine Chemla if the math-history intersection intrigues you. 

- 🥾 Getting outdoors more often. Whether it's walking my dog, running, or backpacking for a couple of days, I've been making a conscious effort to rejuvenate my mind and avoid any shred of mental stagnancy at all costs. Side note: I saw my first barn owl last night (indeed, I love birdwatching). 

- 📚 🇫🇷 Cultivating a couple of daily habits. I have made doing (duo-ing?) my Duolingo lessons a priority, and I now realize that my years of Latin are finally paying off with other European languages. I've also made daily reading a priority, and I have set a fairly modest goal of one book a month. I'm right on track so far!

I'm very proud of (1) my work and (2) my work-life balance thus far, and I'm absolutely looking forward to the upcoming academic year. There are various reflections that I've unearthed over the past 6 months or so, and I certainly plan to articulate them here towards the end of this summer!

Rao Ma
        
              
          Excited to be at #EMNLP2024 in Miami! ☀️🌴 Join us for our "Muting Whisper" poster at Session D on Wednesday, 10:30-12:00. See you there! 🚀

Recent developments in large speech models like OpenAI's Whisper have revolutionized automatic speech recognition (ASR). However, our latest research reveals a critical vulnerability in these systems.

🔍 Key Findings: We discovered that Whisper's use of special tokens, such as <endoftext>, can be exploited by adversarial attacks. By inserting a learned universal 0.64-second audio segment, we can "mute" the model, forcing it to ignore actual speech and transcribe only the special token. This attack was effective over 97% of the time, even across different datasets and tasks!

💡 Why It Matters:
Risks: Potential misuse to bypass speech moderation systems.
Opportunities: A novel way to protect private speech data.
This research opens up important discussions on the security and ethics of deploying large ASR models in real-world applications.

📄 Thanks to the first author Vyas Raina and other coauthors Charles McGhee Kate Knill Mark Gales. Read the full paper at https://lnkd.in/gZhRDfAt and try our code at https://lnkd.in/g4bNrawD to explore our methods and implications for future ASR systems.

Rolando Rivera
        
              
          Hello LinkedIn Friends,  

I’m excited to introduce you to Nolan Maske from NCA&T University. Nolan and his team won first place in the Fall 2024 Hackathon with Goldman Sachs!

Even more impressive is the application they developed to win the competition. They created a web app called PredictFi, designed to predict future earnings for financial companies. Congratulations, Nolan and team! 

If you follow my posts on LinkedIn, you know that Market Leader Game (MLG) also predicts future earnings. At first glance, you might think PredictFi and MLG are similar.  Both use statistical modeling to forecast earnings. For example, MLG’s algorithm identifies NASDAQ or NYSE stock symbols that are most likely to experience significant price increases over the next 12 months.

@Nolan, it would be fascinating to learn more about the context and objectives behind future earnings predictions in PredictFi.

MLG selects stock symbols with the highest probable growth rates by combining and then comparing:
- Monte Carlo-generated stock prices,
- Actual growth rates from the past 12 months, and
- Detailed analysis of income statements and balance sheets.

I purchased 3 stocks in 05/24 and 2 more in 10/24 to test the model.  The performance (as of today) has been remarkable  - 148% growth in 6 months:

The difference between MLG and PredictFi became clearer when I asked Nolan if his team used another statistical model to derive future earnings. 

Nolan replied (paraphrasing):
"PredictFi uses ARIMA  (AutoRegressive Integrated Moving Average). The application assumes past patterns in data will continue. The team did not have sufficient time to explore the uncertainties and random outcomes that Monte Carlo could address."

His response piqued my interest, leading me to dive deeper into the differences between Monte Carlo Simulation and ARIMA.

Here’s what I found:

ARIMA Modeling Strengths:

Time-series focus: Well-suited for capturing trends, seasonality, and autocorrelations in stock prices.

Deterministic forecasts: Based on past patterns and relationships within the data.

Simpler assumptions: Assumes that historical patterns will persist.

Monte Carlo Simulation Strengths:
Flexibility: Models multiple potential price paths using randomness and volatility.

Captures stochastic behavior: Reflects the uncertainty and randomness of financial markets.

Use Case: Best for long-term risk assessment, scenario analysis, and when uncertainty and volatility are key factors.


Conclusion

Use ARIMA for short-term forecasting and when historical trends dominate.
Use Monte Carlo for long-term forecasting, risk assessment, and probabilistic scenarios.

Combining these methods or integrating them with other models (e.g., machine learning or GARCH for volatility analysis) often yields the best insights.

I hope this comparison sheds some light on these powerful predictive tools. 

Congratulations again to Nolan and his team for their impressive achievement!
